item.title: Roblox: Basketball Zero Codes (July 2025)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All Basketball Zero Codes
  • How to Redeem Codes for Basketball Zero
  • How to Get More Basketball Zero Codes

Basketball Zero is a fast-paced and simple in gameplay mechanics basketball simulator that can easily drag you into long hours of play. Also, between matches, you can spin for different Styles and Zones of play, and if you're lucky, get some cool skills that will help you during the game.

Actually, to succeed and get legendary or even mythical Styles or Zones, you will need to spend a lot of time getting Spins. To partially make it easier, just like in other Roblox games, in Basketball Zero , you can redeem codes that will bring you a lot of Spins and even Lucky Spins.

Updated July 12, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: Basketball Zero has introduced new rewards you can claim right now. These latest additions offer Spins, giving you more chances to unlock useful items or make progress. It's a good time to log in and take advantage of what's available. Be sure to check back for future updates.

All Basketball Zero Codes

Working Basketball Zero Codes

  • UNCLESAM - Redeem this code to get Spins. (NEW)
  • VERYSRRYDELAY - Redeem this code to get Spins. (NEW)
  • OIL - Redeem this code to get Spins. (NEW)

Redeeming Basketball Zero codes is one of the few ways to get Spins, and it's a very effective one at that. So, don't miss this opportunity to get some freebies, because each code has a certain expiration date, after which it becomes invalid and offers no rewards.

How to Redeem Codes for Basketball Zero

Redeeming Basketball Zero codes is no more difficult than in most other Roblox games and will take you a few clicks. Here is also an informative and clear guide on how to redeem Basketball Zero codes and get rewards:

  • Launch Basketball Zero .
  • Pay attention to the bottom of the screen. There will be a bunch of buttons placed in a row. Among them, interact with the last one, which says Codes.
  • This will open the redemption menu. There will be an input field and a green Redeem button. Now, in the input field, enter manually, or better yet, copy and paste one of the above-mentioned working codes.
  • Lastly, click on the green Redeem button to submit your reward request.

If everything is done correctly, a notification will appear on the screen with a list of rewards received.

How to Get More Basketball Zero Codes

To find more Roblox codes and, therefore, more rewards, you will need to visit and carefully monitor the main official Basketball Zero social media pages. The developers often share codes when the community reaches a goal of likes rated for the game, so just visit these pages from time to time to see the progress:

  • Official Basketball Zero Roblox group.
  • Official Basketball Zero Discord server.
  • Official Basketball Zero YouTube channel.

item.title: Umamusume: Pretty Derby - Biwa Hayahide Build & Stats Guide
item.description:
Biwa Hayahide is one of the strongest horse girls in Umamusume: Pretty Derby , and her abilities as a Medium/Long-distance Pace Chaser sets her apart from the rest of the game's roster. Biwa Hayahide still needs the right set of Support Cards and skills to win races, though, so she's not a one-way ticket to victory for Umamusume trainers.

Biwa Hayahide is a limited character, so she's only available while her banner is still active. Otherwise, you'll have to wait for a rerun to get another chance to unlock her. Biwa Hayahide has a fairly straightforward game plan, so most Umamusume trainers should already have most of the Support Cards and strategies necessary to win with her in career mode.

Best Stats for Biwa Hayahide

Biwa Hayahide is a Medium/Long distance Pace Chaser (with a B rating for Late Surger ), so she needs a lot of Speed and Power to come out on top of the competition. As always, prioritize Speed above all else. It's the most important stat for all Umamusume characters, and Biwa Hayahide is no different.

Power is the second most important stat for Biwa Hayahide since she'll need to pass plenty of other Umamusume in the final stretch of a race. Guts also helps here, but it's not as important. Biwa Hayahide does have a 10% bonus to her Guts growth rate , though, so you won't need to devote as much time to it.

Wit is also pretty important for Biwa Hayahide, but you don't need to train it that often. She has a 20% Wit growth rate bonus by default, and most Umamusume don't need that much Wit to activate their skills during races. Biwa Hayahide makes use of more skills than the average racer, though, so don't neglect Wit.

Stamina is important for Biwa Hayahide since she specializes in some of the longest races the game has to offer, but most of her Stamina recovery will come from skills. You should still train Stamina to make sure she has a solid baseline to work with, but skills like Stamina to Spare and Deep Breaths will help her maintain her energy until she needs it in the final stretch.

Best Support Cards for Biwa Hayahide

The best Support Card deck for Biwa Hayahide includes four Speed cards and a mixture of Power and Guts cards to fill in the remaining slots. You can even toss in a Wit Support Card to get some extra skills under her belt, especially some Stamina recovery abilities.

These are some of the best Support Cards you can use with Biwa Hayahide in Umamusume: Pretty Derby:

  • Special Week (Speed)
  • Special Week (Guts)
  • Super Creek (Stamina)
  • Nishino Flower (Speed)
  • Fine Motion (Wit)
  • Tokai Teio (Speed)
  • El Condor Pasa (Power)
  • Mejiro McQueen (Stamina)
  • Gold Ship (Stamina)
  • Air Shakur (Wit)

Both Special Week SSR Support Cards are great fits for Biwa Hayahide since they come with multiple Stamina recovery skills and Speed boosts for the last spurt of races. Super Creek also remains one of the best Support Cards for Stamina recovery thanks to her Swinging Maestro skill, so she can fit into Biwa Hayahide's deck even though Stamina cards aren't ideal. Fine Motion is another excellent choice for Biwa Hayahide as well, since her Speed Star skill is great for Pace Chasers.

Best Biwa Hayahide Skills in Umamusume

These are the best skills you should unlock for Biwa Hayahide in Umamusume .

  • win Q.E.D.
  • Swinging Maestro
  • Speed Star
  • Technician
  • Shatterproof
  • Dazzling Disorientation
  • Pace Chaser Savvy
  • Hydrate
  • Stamina to Spare
  • Shrewd Step
  • Prepared to Pass
  • Pace Chaser Corners
  • Passing Pro
  • Deep Breaths
  • Pressure
  • Up-Tempo
  • Killer Tunes
  • Thunderbolt Step

All of these skills improve Biwa Hayahide's performance in Medium/Long races or give her additional bursts of Speed during the critical moments toward the end of a race. Her ideal strategy is really straightforward, so just unlock as many skills that say Long, Medium, or Pace in their descriptions, and you'll be set. Biwa Hayahide is one of the strongest Pace Chasers in Umamusume , after all, and she'll make a great addition to your SSR roster.

5 Images

item.title: Despite Not Being Playable in Marvel Rivals, This Character Can Be Found Everywhere in the Game
item.description:
Marvel Rivals is a true celebration of the Marvel universe, including everything from fan-favorite characters and locations to deep cut references. While the game is accessible to Marvel newcomers, longtime fans of the universe will get a lot out of Marvel Rivals . The playable roster in Marvel Rivals includes heroes and villains from all corners of the Marvel universe, giving players a diverse cast to play as. Marvel Rivals will be adding new characters every 45 days, meaning players won’t have a shortage of characters to choose from. However, there is one character that can be seen all throughout the game, and yet, they still don’t have a place among the rest of the playable cast: Deadpool.

Marvel Rivals Is Full of References to Deadpool

Wolverine Cosmetic Bundle

To tie-in with Deadpool & Wolverine , Marvel Rivals added a skin for Wolverine based on his costume from the movie. While the skin itself may be a subtle hint that Marvel Rivals will add the other half of the duo eventually, the most crucial piece of evidence is the accompanying spray. Players who bought the bundle for this Marvel Rivals Wolverine cosmetic were given a spray that is Wolverine’s mask represented as half of a heart. The missing half is undoubtedly reserved for Deadpool when he is eventually added to the game. Like the Wolverine cosmetic, it’s likely that Deadpool’s equivalent of this spray will be available as part of a cosmetic bundle based on his MCU appearance.

Marvel Snap Collab

Soon after the initial of Marvel Rivals ’, the game collaborated with Marvel Snap , a collectible card game featuring characters from the Marvel universe. As part of this crossover promotion, new cosmetics were added to Marvel Rivals for players to enjoy. One of these is the Marvel Snap Nameplate, which shows Deadpool with his face full of arrows. While the game has alluded to Deadpool prior to this, the Nameplate is one of the first times the character himself can be seen in Marvel Rivals . Though he is yet to be included as a playable hero, he’s still been a part of the game since its early stages with this Nameplate.

Squirrel Girl Lore

On the Hero Profiles of each of Marvel Rivals ’ playable characters, a Lore tab can be found, which gives players an insight into the backstories of the game’s cast. In Squirrel Girl’s BFFFs hero story, Psylocke mentions a “strange man in red” who was sent to find her. The description is vague, but it seems like it could be alluding to Deadpool. Though there are plenty of Marvel superheroes who wear red costumes, the key piece of information is that this mysterious character wasn’t looking for Psylocke for their own reasons; they were sent by someone else to find her. As the merc with a mouth, it could be possible that Deadpool was hired to track Psylocke down and will eventually catch up to her when he joins the Marvel Rivals cast.

Deadpool Accessory

As of July 11, a new type of cosmetic has been added to Marvel Rivals . As well as customizing their character’s costumes, sprays and emotes, players now have the option to add Accessories to certain heroes. These can be seen on the character model, but it also adds an icon to the side of the player’s screen which reacts to KOs. One Accessory that players can have hanging from Jeff’s fin is a Deadpool Plush, inserting the character into Marvel Rivals again before he’s found a place on the roster. Many of the other Accessories are based on characters who are already playable in the game, so this could be a hint that Deadpool is on the way very soon.

Jeff Handbag Accessory

The Jeff the Land Shark Handbag Accessory, much like the Deadpool Plush, is another cosmetic available to players from the new Accessory system. Exclusive to Emma Frost, the Jeff Handbag can give players a new way to style the character on the battlefield. The handbag is more than just a cute add-on, though, as it is a direct reference to the Deadpool comics. Emma mentioned to Deadpool that Jeff looks like a “handbag with legs and teeth”, much to Deadpool’s dismay. It’s likely that, when he is added to the game, Deadpool will share his disapproval of Emma’s Accessory in a unique character interaction.

Deadpool Could Be Joining Marvel Rivals Very Soon

Deadpool’s inclusion in Marvel Rivals has always been a matter of when, not if. Marvel Rivals leaks have been hinting at Deadpool for quite some time, and with each new reference to him in the game, it seems like it won’t be long before he is finally playable. The inclusion of Jean Grey and Blade in Season 3 means that he won’t be added this season, but it’s possible that he could be added to the roster in Season 4.

The remaining quandary with Deadpool is what type of character he will be. Typically, he has used an assortment of guns and blades throughout his major appearances, making Duelist the likely choice, but this may not be for the best. Fans of the character remember him most for his eccentric personality and humor, so the funniest option may be to make Deadpool a Strategist in Marvel Rivals . This could work surprisingly well with the character, and would alleviate player concerns that the game is becoming overrun with Duelists.

Deadpool’s presence in Marvel Rivals can’t be easily ignored. From his inclusion as a plush Accessory to possible mentions in another character’s lore, it’s impossible for players to avoid him. He’s become one of the most prominent characters in Marvel media, and with each new character reveal, Deadpool’s omission from the Marvel Rivals roster becomes more noticeable. Every additional reference to the character in each of the game’s updates makes it seem as though Deadpool will not be missing for long, though, possibly even becoming playable in the game’s next season.

item.title: Even Though Marvel's Spider-Man 3 is Years Away, Its Version of SM2's Doctor Strange Mission is Already Clear
item.description:
Only time will tell what exactly Marvel's Spider-Man 3 will look like, but Insomniac is definitely riding high on its superhero series so far; hopefully, the studio will manage to keep its momentum going for the third mainline entry in the franchise. That's a little easier said than done, though, since Marvel's Spider-Man 3 will be tasked with outdoing three best-selling critically-acclaimed web-slinger games—no simple feat.

Aside from the requisite twists, turns, and miscellaneous subversive elements that one would expect from an ambitious AAA sequel, Marvel's Spider-Man 3 will need to up the ante on Spidey's story. After Marvel's Spider-Man 2 , it might seem like there's not much more room for the franchise to grow, since iconic villains like Venom and Doc Ock have already had their time in this universe's spotlight. Of course, there's a good chance that the Green Goblin will appear in Spider-Man 3 , but that's just the big bad: there needs to be other intense action set-pieces, side quests, and minor arcs involving disparate aspects of the Spider-Man mythos, and synergizing with the upcoming Spider-Man: Brand New Day film might not be a bad place to start.

Marvel's Spider-Man 3 Can Repeat the Success of the Dr. Strange Mission with Hulk, Punisher

The Doctor Strange Portal Mission Is Among Spider-Man 2's Best

Regrettably, Doctor Strange doesn't actually appear in Spider-Man 2 , but some of his gear does: Black Cat obtains a magical portal-creating wand that Miles Morales is tasked with retrieving, and a high-speed, flashy chase sequence ensues. It's one of the most memorable parts of the game, since the device is constantly creating rips in space-time, sending the player to the other side of the map, or even the other side of the world.

This sequence was likely included to show off the PS5's hardware capabilities, and Insomniac already had experience with similar mechanics via Ratchet and Clank: Rift Apart , but it's quite possible that the MCU, and specifically Spider-Man: No Way Home , played a big role in its inclusion as well.

No Way Home features a similar portal-laden set piece, and this could have indirectly or directly influenced the aforementioned Black Cat chase in Spider-Man 2 —Insomniac does work closely with Marvel Studios during development, after all, so it could very well have had advance knowledge of such a scene while making the game. If one assumes this is the case, then it has some promising implications for Spider-Man 3 .

Spider-Man: Brand New Day's Cameos Could Set Spider-Man 3 Up To Outdo Its Predecessor

It's been confirmed that Jon Bernthal's Punisher will play a role in the upcoming film Spider-Man: Brand New Day , and it's been strongly rumored that a rendition of Savage Hulk will make an appearance as well. If Insomniac wishes to implement some creative synergy with Brand New Day , as it did with No Way Home , then using at least one of these characters for a high-stakes side mission or set piece seems like a no-brainer.

In the comics, Spider-Man and the Punisher cross paths quite regularly, as they are both New York City vigilantes, albeit with starkly different methods. As such, it would be fitting for Insomniac's version(s) of Spider-Man to butt heads with Frank Castle at some point, perhaps prompting the player to chase him down and bring him to justice, queuing up a morally complex subplot.

The Hulk would be another welcome face in Spider-Man 3 , and there are even more—and more outrageous—gameplay opportunities that could be designed around him. Another chase or even a boss fight against Hulk would be a great opportunity for mechanical experimentation and hard-hitting storytelling, regardless of the character's potential inclusion in the next Spider-Man film. The link between the movie and the film would just serve as an additional bit of motivation for Insomniac in this respect.

item.title: 8 Best SNES RPGs You’ve Probably Never Heard Of
item.description:
Summary

  • SNES RPGs like The Adventures of Hourai High offer gameplay that holds up to this day.
  • SNES RPGs, like Albert Odyssey, were not widely released but still deserve recognition.
  • SD Gundam Gaiden: Knight Gundam Monogatari is a unique RPG on SNES with a silly twist.

The NES was Nintendo’s greatest achievement, which helped revive the console market. This then led to the Game Boy, their first portable, and their console successor, the SNES. For many, SNES titles remain some of the best games that hold up to this day, thanks to their improved gameplay loops, enhanced graphics, and, in some cases, more compelling stories.

RPGs are great examples that are as easy to go back to today as they were in the 90s. Even though the SNES was popular globally, that didn’t mean every game was released on a wide scale or even released at all. These RPGs still rip, but they are a bit more obscure than most.

8 The Adventures of Hourai High

Move Over Persona

  • Developer: J-Wing
  • Publisher: J-Wing
  • Released: April 19, 1996
  • Platform: SNES

The Adventures of Hourai High is a Japanese SNES RPG that takes place on an island with an exclusive academy on it that players will parachute onto at the start. Everyone has their allegiances and players, as a newbie, will go through each club to take them down a peg or two and make their way to the top.

Fighting club members are one thing, but there are also mutated animals to deal with on this mysterious island. Persona fans who like school-based RPGs should look this one up, as fans have translated it into English.

7 Albert Odyssey

Two Missing Games

Albert Odyssey: Legend of Eldean
Released
August 9, 1996

Platform(s)
Sega Saturn
Powered by

Sega Saturn RPG fans probably played Albert Odyssey: Legend of Eldean , or at least heard about it in the 90s, which is a decent turn-based RPG. What they may not know is that there were two SNES games that preceded it.

The first Albert Odyssey is quite different, too, as there are strategic elements involving invading kingdoms on the world map. There is a fan patch for it, but not the sequel so far. Either way, tactical RPG fans who like weird systems should check out the first Albert Odyssey .

6 Arcana

Heart Of The Dungeon Crawler

Arcana
RPG
Systems
Released
March 27, 1992
ESRB
t
Developer(s)
HAL Laboratory

Powered by

Arcana is a relatively obscure RPG for the SNES that was surprisingly released on the console in North America despite its Japan-heavy vibe. Players control a Card Master named Rooks, who can summon other party members on his travels. Players will traverse through dungeons in first-person with their party of four, fighting animated cards along the way.

Like Fire Emblem , players have to be careful about progressing their party members as Arcana is a linear experience going from dungeon to dungeon, which makes it more challenging, but that’s not necessarily a bad thing.

5 Brain Lord

An Enix Enigma

Brain Lord
Released
January 27, 1994

Platform(s)
SNES
Powered by

Brain Lord is not a descriptive title for the game, and the box art for North America doesn’t help either. It can best be described as a top-down action RPG with an emphasis on puzzles, which may be where the inspiration for the title came from.

Despite the big blocky frame of the hero, players will move quite fast through dungeons, and the weapon range is decent for a SNES game. There are no humanoid party members, but players can summon faeries and use other magic while in combat. It’s not Enix’s best RPG on the SNES, but it does occupy that hidden gem territory.

4 Brandish

Another Series Of Missing Sequels

  • Developer: Nihon Falcom
  • Publisher: Koei
  • Released: August 11, 1995 (Japan, SNES Version)
  • Platforms: SNES, PC

Brandish is another series that has some mysterious sequels lying in wait in Japan. Brandish wasn’t a huge RPG on the SNES in North America, but some may have played it. There was a sequel released in Japan on both Japanese computers and the SNES called Brandish 2: The Planet Buster , and yes, there is a fan patch.

It was a top-down action RPG that played more like a classic roguelike of the 90s. It was a fairly big RPG series for Japanese players, at least as there were two more sequels on PC. The first game even got remade for the PSP, which was released outside of Japan, but Westerners probably didn’t know that existed either.

3 Emerald Dragon

Release The Dragon

  • Developer: Alfa System (SNES Version)
  • Publisher: MediaWorks (SNES Version)
  • Released: July 28, 1995 (SNES Version)
  • Platforms: PC, SNES, TurboGrafx-16

Before players were tearing it up as the Dovahkiin in The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim , they were a Dragonborn in Emerald Dragon . Releasing only in Japan, players assumed the Dragonborn Atorushan, who transformed into a man to aid a young girl’s request in the human world.

While Atorushan gains party members, only he can be controlled in battle, which operates like small-scale tactical encounters. The AI-based system is not ideal, but party members are smart enough for an SNES game. From the colorful sprites to the expressive anime-inspired character portraits, this RPG is waiting to be discovered, and there is a fan patch.

2 Inindo: Way Of The Ninja

Before Assassin’s Creed: Shadows There Was…

Inindo: Way of the Ninja
Released
July 19, 1991

Platform(s)
MS-DOS, SNES, MSX, PC
Powered by

Assassin’s Creed: Shadows gave fans a ninja and samurai RPG rolled into one that they have been wanting for a while. It was far from the first samurai or ninja RPG, though, as there was a decent one on the SNES called Inindo: Way of the Ninja.

Players were a lowly ninja at the start who tried to make alliances to take down the evil Lord Nobunaga, a tale that Assassin’s Creed: Shadows will find familiar. It doesn’t have the flashiest combat on the SNES, but it is unique in its setting, and it did release on the SNES in North America along with other platforms.

1 SD Gundam Gaiden: Knight Gundam Monogatari - Ooinaru Isan

Mechs Going Medieval

  • Developer: Tose
  • Publisher: Angel
  • Released: December 21, 1991 (Japan)
  • Platform: SNES

The SNES is absolutely flooded with Gundam games or other anime games that fans have probably never heard of, including RPGs. One of the strangest is SD Gundam Gaiden: Knight Gundam Monogatari - Ooinaru Isan , which makes the most sense from an RPG point of view but less sense as a Gundam game.

It’s framed like a Dragon Quest adventure, except that familiar-looking mechs will be clad in armor or have horns like they are monsters. It’s very silly, and unfortunately, there is no fan patch yet.
